tool.name: BIANA
tool.help:
Biologic Interactions And Network Analysis ========================================== BIANA is a integration and network management framework of interactomics data. The integration protocol uses a high level abstraction schema where any data source, i.e. a database of interactomics data (e.g. IntAct), included in BIANA is defined as an external database, where both participants and relations are considered as external entities, characterized by several attributes. BIANA's unique unification protocol, a set of rules that determine how data in various data sources are combined, and its traceability, i.e. the attributes contained in each unified entity can always be traced back to its original source. This properties allow BIANA to offer the possibility to the user to create its own unification protocols, a feature missing in most database unification frameworks.
Inputs ====== Biana takes a single file as input, along with a number of parameters.
Seeds ----- These are the bioentities for which BIANA will search for interactions. They are passed in a single file, one entity per line. An example file might look like this:
HDA1_YEAST MNP1_YEAST HSP92_YEAST
Seed Type --------- This is the type of identifiers specified in the seeds file.
Radius ------ The radius represents the depth of the generated network (tree). A radius of 1 will create a network containing the seeds and their direct interaction partners. A depth of 2 will also contain the interactions partners of interaction partners etc. The size of the network grows exponentially with radius, expect longer computation times for large radii. A radius of 0 creates a network without depth limit, needless to say this will take a long time.
Method Restrictions ------------------- You can restrict the methods that BIANA uses to predict interactions.
Species Restrictions ------------- This option restricts the network of interactions to those entities of the chosen species.
Output Translation Type ----------------------- The output identifier type you want to use for the output.
Output ====== This tool produces three output files. One contains a list of nodes of the generated network, one contains a list of edges and the last contains translations from the BIANA codes used in the other files to identifiers of the output translation type. The files are space separated.
